thread.title: David Davis: Parliament will not block Brexit
thread.title_full: David Davis: Parliament will not block Brexit

author: Laura Hughes
title: David Davis: Parliament will not block Brexit
text:
David Davis: Parliament will not block Brexit 18 January 2017 • 8:26am Theresa May vows to leave Single Market Parliament will get vote on final Brexit deal 'No deal' better than 'bad deal', PM warns EU 8:19AM Boris: Countries 'queuing up' for trade deals 
W riting in the Telegraph this morning, the Foreign Secretary has said there is already a high demand for trade deals with the UK from countries around the world, although they will have to wait until the end of Article 50 negotiations in 2019. 
"They are already queuing up," Mr Johnson wrote. 
"Under EU rules, we are not formally allowed to negotiate these new treaties until we leave. But there is nothing to say that ideas cannot be pencilled in." 
He added that Britain will not be "slamming the door to migrants" and will remain open to "talent" from the EU. 
Mrs May delivered her long-awaited speech on Brexit under the buzz phrase "Global Britain" and stressed her plan would allow the country to be "more outward looking than ever before". Britain's Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson Credit: Matej Leskovsek MPs will not block Brexit 
G ood Morning, 
Theresa May has said a final deal on Britain's exit from the EU will be put to a vote of both Houses of Parliament. 
Speaking on Sky News this morning, her Brexit Secretary David Davis has insisted that Britain will still leave the EU if MPs vote against the Prime Minister's deal. 
Mr Davis said: “We don’t intend to vote against it, the whole point of this is to get a good deal…” Watch | Theresa May's Brexit speech highlights 01:52 
“It has been very plain, we have given Parliament what they have asked for. It will be the last of a series of votes on this subject. We are optimistic we are going to get a good deal. 
“We have been very clear about the deal we are looking for. WE have designed a deal which we think will get the support of a very large people who voted to Remain as well as those who voted to leave. 
“The aim is to get as much of the country behind us as we can. And we are confident that we will win that vote at the end.” Theresa May’s Brexit speech | Key points 
I t comes after Mrs May warned the European Union that she is prepared to walk away from the negotiating table as she set out her blueprint for Brexit . 
In comments that were hailed by Eurosceptics, the Prime Minister told EU leaders yesterday that any attempt to “punish” Britain would be “an act of calamitous self-harm for the countries of Europe” that her Government will not accept. 
She said she would rather do “no deal” than one which is a “bad deal for Britain” and said that any attempt by the EU to harm the UK would force her to change the country’s “economic model” by lowering tax and cutting regulation to compete with Brussels. Follow Telegraph News
